Question: 11. Ovarian stimulation as part of an IVF procedure is realized via:
OptionC: High-dose progesterone during the follicular phase
OptionD: Blocking GnRH receptors only after ovulation
OptionE: Oxytocin infusion to induce follicle rupture
Explanation:
Correct: A. Injection of gonadotropins (FSH ± LH/hMG)
Concept: Controlled ovarian stimulation aims to recruit multiple follicles for oocyte retrieval.
  • Gonadotropins (recombinant FSH, hMG) directly stimulate follicular growth.
  • In IVF protocols, GnRH agonists/antagonists may be used to prevent premature LH surge, but the core stimulation is by gonadotropins.

Question: 12. Which of the zona pellucida proteins acts as a receptor for spermatozoa binding?
Explanation:
Correct: C. ZP3
High-yield mechanism: ZP3 mediates initial sperm binding and triggers the acrosome reaction (classic exam formulation).
  • ZP2 is more associated with post-acrosome binding and helps maintain sperm attachment.
  • ZP1 cross-links ZP filaments, giving structural integrity.

Question: 13. The notochord is under which structure?
Explanation:
Correct: B. The neural tube
Spatial anatomy (midline): Neural tube lies dorsal to the notochord; notochord lies ventral to it.
Clinical integration: Notochord patterns the neural tube (Shh signaling), and remnants contribute to nucleus pulposus.

Question:
14. Match each of the listed tissues and the characteristic location of this tissue:
Back:
OptionA:
Dense irregular connective tissue => Deep layer of the dermis
Elastic connective tissue => ligg. flava
Bone tissue => Skeleton
Reticular connective tissue => Spleen stroma
Mucous connective tissue => Umbilical cord
OptionB:
Dense irregular connective tissue => Papillary dermis
Elastic connective tissue => Tendons
Bone tissue => Lymph node stroma
Reticular connective tissue => Umbilical cord
Mucous connective tissue => Skeleton
OptionC:
Dense irregular connective tissue => Liver parenchyma
Elastic connective tissue => Dermis
Bone tissue => ligg. flava
Reticular connective tissue => Tendons
Mucous connective tissue => Spleen capsule
OptionD:
Dense irregular connective tissue => Umbilical cord
Elastic connective tissue => Deep dermis
Bone tissue => ligg. flava
Reticular connective tissue => Skeleton
Mucous connective tissue => Spleen stroma
OptionE:
Dense irregular connective tissue => Epidermis
Elastic connective tissue => Cartilage matrix
Bone tissue => Dermis
Reticular connective tissue => Myocardium
Mucous connective tissue => Dura mater
Explanation:
Correct: A
How to discriminate (MU-Varna style):
  • Dense irregular CT: thick collagen bundles in many directions → reticular (deep) dermis.
  • Elastic CT: abundant elastic fibers → ligamenta flava (yellow ligaments).
  • Reticular CT: type III collagen framework → stroma of spleen (also lymph nodes, BM).
  • Mucous CT (Wharton’s jelly): gelatinous ground substance → umbilical cord.

Question: 15. The number of somites at the end of the 5th week of development is:
Explanation:
Correct: D. 42–44 pairs
Exam hook: Somites form in a cranio-caudal sequence. By the end of week 5, the embryo typically has about 42–44 pairs (some regress later, e.g., coccygeal).

Question: 16. Neurons with typical pyramid shape soma are the:
OptionA: Purkinje cells of the cerebellar cortex
OptionE: Pseudounipolar neurons of dorsal root ganglia
Explanation:
Correct: B. Giant cells of Betz
Key morphology: Pyramidal neurons have a triangular/pyramidal soma with an apical dendrite, typical for the cerebral cortex.
  • Betz cells: large pyramidal neurons in primary motor cortex (layer V).
  • Purkinje cells are flask-shaped, not pyramidal.

Question: 17. Where else in the cell are localized the ribosomes?
OptionA: In the nucleus attached to chromatin
OptionB: On the surface of the rough ER
Explanation:
Correct: B. On the surface of the rough ER
Core idea: Ribosomes are found free in cytosol or bound to RER.
  • RER-bound ribosomes synthesize proteins destined for secretion, membranes, and lysosomes.
  • Ribosomes are not located in lysosomes or Golgi lumen.

Question: 18. In the 3rd week of embryogenesis, the lateral edges of the neural plate fold and meet to form the neural tube. This process is called:
Explanation:
Correct: B. Neurulation
Definition: Folding of the neural plate to form the neural tube (CNS primordium).
Clinical note: Failure of closure → neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida, anencephaly).

Question: 20. The primitive endothelial cells are formed by:
OptionA: Neural crest cells migrating into the mesenchyme
OptionC: Epiblast cells remaining on the surface
Explanation:
Correct: B. Cells lining the yolk sac
Mechanism: Early vasculogenesis begins in the extraembryonic mesoderm of the yolk sac forming blood islands.
  • Peripheral cells of blood islands → endothelial lining
  • Central cells → primitive blood cells

Question: 22. Which of the following structures is present in electrical synapses?
Explanation:
Correct: B. Connexons
Electrical synapse = gap junction. Each channel is formed by aligned connexons (hexamers of connexins) from adjacent cells.
Function: rapid, bidirectional ionic current flow, synchronized activity (e.g., some neurons, cardiac/smooth muscle coupling).

Question: 24. The straited (skeletal) muscle tissue has
OptionA: Gap junctions enabling a functional syncytium
OptionB: Cells with a single central nucleus
OptionC: Short, branched fibers with intercalated discs
OptionE: None of the answers in correct
Explanation:
Correct: E. None of the answers in correct
Why all A–D are wrong for skeletal muscle:
  • A: functional syncytium via gap junctions is cardiac/smooth, not skeletal.
  • B: skeletal fibers are multinucleated with peripheral nuclei.
  • C: branching + intercalated discs are cardiac features.
  • D: skeletal muscle is voluntary and depends on motor innervation.

Question: 25. The sarcomere is the part of the myofibril between:
Explanation:
Correct: B. The two Z-discs
Definition: Sarcomere = contractile unit from Z-disc to Z-disc.
  • Z-disc: anchors actin (thin filaments) via α-actinin.
  • Shortening occurs mainly by sliding filament mechanism.

Question: 26. Which term does not belong to the others?
Explanation:
Correct: E. Brain
Logic: A–D are neuroglial cell types (supporting cells). Brain is an organ/structure, not a cell type.

Question: 27. Which type of neuroglial cells provide myelin in the central nervous system?
Explanation:
Correct: B. Oligodendrocytes
  • CNS myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes (one cell can myelinate multiple axons).
  • PNS myelin is produced by Schwann cells (one cell per axon segment).

Question: 28. Which statement is FALSE?
OptionA: Smooth muscle is present in the wall of the intestine
OptionB: Smooth muscle is present in the wall of the uterus
OptionC: Smooth muscle helps regulate the diameter of arteries
OptionD: The smooth muscle tissue is involved in building the capillary wall
OptionE: Smooth muscle is found in the wall of the urinary bladder
Explanation:
Correct: D. The smooth muscle tissue is involved in building the capillary wall
Why false: Capillary walls consist of a single layer of endothelial cells plus basal lamina (with pericytes in many capillaries), but no smooth muscle layer.
Clinical link: Precapillary sphincters and arterioles contain smooth muscle, which controls flow into capillary beds.

Question: 29. Troponin is a complex of:
Explanation:
Correct: B. 3 polypeptides
Components:
  • TnC: binds Ca2+
  • TnI: inhibitory, blocks actin–myosin interaction
  • TnT: binds tropomyosin

Question: 30. A neuron with many nerve fibers arising from its cell body and carrying impulses away from the brain would be classified as:
Explanation:
Correct: D. Multipolar neuron
Reasoning: Multipolar neurons have one axon and multiple dendrites and are typical motor neurons carrying impulses away from the CNS.
Contrast: Pseudounipolar neurons are sensory (dorsal root ganglia).

Question: 31. Branched nerve fibers that convey local potential changes toward a cell body of a neuron are called:
Explanation:
Correct: B. Dendrites
Function: Dendrites are branched processes receiving synaptic input and conducting graded potentials toward the soma.
Contrast: Axons conduct action potentials away from the soma.

Question: 32. The gaps between the myelin sheath fragments along an axon are called:
Explanation:
Correct: B. Nodes of Ranvier
High-yield: Nodes are periodic interruptions of myelin where voltage-gated Na+ channels cluster → saltatory conduction.
Trap: Schmidt–Lanterman clefts are cytoplasmic channels within myelin in the PNS.

Question: 33. Structures that form synapses with muscles are:Structures that form synapses with muscles are:
Explanation:
Correct: C. Neuromuscular junctions
Definition: Specialized chemical synapse between a motor neuron terminal and a skeletal muscle fiber (motor end plate).
Key transmitter: Acetylcholine (ACh).

Question: 35. The prophase of the first meiotic division is characterized by the following phases:
OptionC: S phase, G1, G2, M phase, cytokinesis
OptionD: Prophase A, B, C, D, E
Explanation:
Correct: A
Prophase I (meiosis) is subdivided into five classic stages:
  • Leptotene: chromosome condensation begins
  • Zygotene: synapsis starts (bivalents)
  • Pachytene: crossing-over occurs
  • Diplotene: chiasmata visible
  • Diakinesis: maximal condensation, nuclear envelope breakdown

Question: 36. Match the corresponding statements:
Explanation:
Correct: A. Folliculogenesis ⇒ Oogenesis
Meaning: Folliculogenesis is the maturation of ovarian follicles that support the growth and maturation of the oocyte (oogenesis).

Question: 37. The spermatozoa consist of:
Explanation:
Correct: B. Head and tail (flagellum)
  • Head: nucleus + acrosome
  • Tail (flagellum): neck, midpiece (mitochondria), principal piece, end piece

Question: 38. Match the effector nerve endings to their target from the drop list:
OptionA:
Motor nerve endings =>Skeletal muscles
Secretory nerve endings =>Glands
Neuromuscular spindle =>Skeletal muscles
OptionB:
Motor nerve endings => Cardiac muscle
Secretory nerve endings => Glands
Neuromuscular spindle => Tendons
OptionC:
Motor nerve endings => Smooth muscle
Secretory nerve endings => Bone
Neuromuscular spindle => Glands
OptionD:
Motor nerve endings => Glands
Secretory nerve endings => Skeletal muscles
Neuromuscular spindle => Cardiac muscle
OptionE:
Motor nerve endings => Skeletal muscles
Secretory nerve endings => Cartilage
Neuromuscular spindle => Bone
Explanation:
Correct: A
  • Motor nerve endings form neuromuscular junctions on skeletal muscle.
  • Secretory nerve endings innervate glands to regulate secretion.
  • Neuromuscular spindle is a proprioceptive receptor embedded in skeletal muscle.

Question: 39. The speed of impulse conduction along unmyelinated nerve fibers is:
Explanation:
Correct: D. slow
Principle: Unmyelinated fibers conduct via continuous depolarization along the membrane, so conduction is slower than myelinated fibers (no saltatory conduction).

Question: 40. Nodes of the Ranvier are interrupted by:
Explanation:
Correct: A. myelin sheaths
Interpretation (as asked): A node is a gap between myelinated internodes, i.e., it is the point where the continuity of the myelin sheath is interrupted.
Functional result: clustering of Na+ channels → saltatory conduction.
